title: Add segment merged result cache for broker
body:
### Description This PR adds a new cache feature for broker. ### Motivation Currently, the broker can't provide a caching capability for relatively fixed queries need to scan both historical and realtime segments and with time range filter, like the day so far or this week/month/year so far. It would be useful to have a cache feature to cache merged results of historical segments on Broker. It could be expected as a better cache option on Broker for the following use cases. | | Case 1: can work when using group by v2 engine | Case 2: can work when scanning historical segments only | Case 3: can work when scanning both historical and realtime segments | Case 4: be efficient to cache large number of segments | | -------------------- | ---------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------ | | Segment Level cache | ✗ | ✓ | ✓ | ✗ | | Result level cache | ✗ | ✓ | ✗ | ✓ | | **New segment merged cache** | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ | ### Proposed changes |Property|Possible Values|Description|Default| |--------|---------------|-----------|-------| |`druid.broker.cache.useSegmentMergedResultCache`|true, false|Enable segment merged result cache on the Broker. This cache option can be useful for queries need to scan both historical and realtime segments and with time range filter, like the day so far or this week/month/year so far. It can't work together with segment level cache(see `druid.broker.cache.useCache` and `druid.broker.cache.populateCache`) on Broker. If both segment merged result cache and segment level cache are enabled at the same time, then only segment merged result cache will work.|false| |`druid.broker.cache.populateSegmentMergedResultCache`|true, false|Populate segment merged result cache on the Broker. See also `druid.broker.cache.useSegmentMergedResultCache`.|false| ### Rationale As we know that the segment level cache on broker can't work for group by v2 engine and is not very efficient for large number of segments. And the result level cache also can't work for queries need to scan realtime segments. The segment merged result cache tries to solve the limitation of the existing two cache options on Broker. The segment merged result caching feature works like ### Operational impact 1. recommend to increase the `cache.maxEntrySize` on broker 2. the `*/hits` and `*/hitRate` metrics might seem incorrect from query caching hitting view as we need to check extra info from the cache entry to determine whether to accept the entry. The result level cache has same issue. ### Test plan Below is the benchmark result(`useParallelMergePool=true` by default) or view [graph of benchmark result](https://jmh.morethan.io/?gist=5bbb3e650304496f4a566cac8eb4915f) ```text Benchmark (cacheOption) (numHistoircals) (numPeons) (numSegmentsPerHistorial) (numSegmentsPerPeon) (queryGranularity) title: Add two new array functions to Druid
body:
### Description
This PR adds two new array functions to Druid.
| function | description |
| --- | --- |
| array_contains_contiguous_subarray(arr,expr) | returns 1 if the array contains the element specified by expr, or contains contiguous subarray(see [substring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Substring)) specified by expr if expr is an array, else 0 |
| array_contains_subsequence(arr,expr) | returns 1 if the array contains the element specified by expr, or contains [subsequence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsequence) specified by expr if expr is an array, else 0 |

The two array functions can be typically used as filters on [multi-value dimensions](https://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/querying/multi-value-dimensions.html) to do funnel analysis for user behaviour analytics.
Below is a simple example of user behaviour data
```json
{"timestamp": "2011-01-12T00:00:00.000Z", "user": "id1", "events": ["login","home","search"]} 
{"timestamp": "2011-01-13T00:00:00.000Z", "user": "id2", "events": ["home","search","shop"]} 
{"timestamp": "2011-01-14T00:00:00.000Z", "user": "id3", "events": ["home","product","cart"]}
```
We can query how many users get through a series of steps
```sql
select APPROX_COUNT_DISTINCT(user) from ds_name where MV_CONTAINS_SUBSEQUENCE(events, ARRAY['home', 'product'])
```


##### Key changed/added classes in this PR
 * `Function`
 * `ArrayContainsSubsequenceOperatorConversion`
 * `ArrayContainsContiguousSubarrayOperatorConversion`
 * `MultiValueStringOperatorConversions`

<hr>

Fixes #11948 

### Description
For queries on logical values, e.g. `SELECT 1337`, we need not check for
a filter on `__time` column even if `requireTimeCondition` is true.

title: Break down CalciteQueryTest
body:
CalciteQueryTest is a gigantic test class and adding a test case there is an exercise of its own. My IDE itself hangs whenever I open that class. So here is an initial attempt to break it into three separate test classes. I have created one for every `test*join*` test case and one class for every `testSelect*` test case in CalciteQueryTest.
